What were the key limitations encountere.response:
The passage highlights these key limitations and challenges related to the Open Market Review (OMR) and public review processes:

* **Timeliness and Accuracy of Data:** Suppliers noted that market conditions could change between the time of the OMR and the public review, impacting the accuracy of published data.
* **Supplier Engagement and Responsiveness:** While some suppliers frequently reviewed the OMR, others did not.  This inconsistency, along with the timing of public review publications, created challenges.  The effectiveness of engaging suppliers to ensure interest in the Gigabit Infrastructure Subsidy (GIS) procurements was also being evaluated.
* **Completeness of Responses:**  The evaluation questioned whether all relevant suppliers responded to the OMR and public consultation and if the information provided was accurate.  It also examined how many rejected OMR responses were later accepted.
* **Local Body Expertise:** The evaluation also considered whether Local Bodies possessed the necessary skills and knowledge to assess the validity of information received.
* **Responsiveness to Change:** The evaluation questioned the OMR's adaptability to changes in commercial plans, the broader environment, and suppliers' strategic behavior.
* **Effectiveness of Public Consultation:** The effectiveness of the public consultation in generating valid responses to the OMR was also assessed.  Metrics included the number of responses and the number of valid responses that led to OMR changes.
* **Clarity of Guidance:** The evaluation also questioned if BDUK's published information and guidance were sufficient for network providers to complete the OMR.

The text presents these as areas of investigation rather than definitive conclusions. The evaluation sought to measure these aspects using various metrics (indicated by "X" placeholders in the original text), but the actual results are not provided.

rag_results.text: viable commercially for full fibre deployment will require additional funding of some kind. We estimate this will include around 10% of premises across the UK. These, often rural, areas must not be forced to wait until the rest of the country has connectivity before they can access full fibre networks. Widespread connectivity creates opportunities for small businesses to tap into a global customer base and for people to work more efficiently. We will pursue an ‘outside in’

Programme that can further the delivery of full fibre networks. • The Government will also ensure that programmes delivered through the National Productivity Investment Fund (NPIF) are consistent with the objective of deployment of full fibre across the country. • The Government and Ofcom will consider further how our ambitions for fibre deployment can complement existing programmes including the roll out of the broadband Universal Service Obligation (USO) from 2020 to maximise investment in full fibre.

in this strategy aims to ensure that commercial investment in full fibre networks covers as much of the UK as possible. However, there will be some parts of the country that will be too costly for the market to deliver to alone. These parts of the country are likely to be largely in remote rural areas, with low population densities and, in many cases, topographic challenges. These factors increase the costs of deployment and reduce returns from fewer premises. The

connectivity and recommends that a national full fibre rollout programme should be put in place to achieve nationwide coverage. The analysis we have commissioned in support of this Review indicates that, absent change, full fibre networks will at best only ever reach three quarters of the country, and take more than 20 years to do so.7 This is not good enough to meet our ambition of world class digital connectivity for the UK, with no part of the country being left behind.

ising deployment of full fibre across the country. The Gigabit Broadband Voucher Scheme is already succeeding in stimulating new fibre investment and extending existing deployment plans by funding fibre connections for UK homes and businesses – including in very rural and hard-to-serve areas. The LFFN programme will continue Future Telecoms Infrastructure Review 45 to explore how public sector demand and reuse of public sector assets can support full fibre deployment in these areas. 133.
